messages: 14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:05): one thing I just realized. we've had doctype for ages to signify which version of HTML we're using for standards compliance, but have no indicators for which version of css we're shooting for

14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:07): because "what-if", at some point in the future the html/css becomes more modular in the browsers and more able to be easily and incrementally tweaked over time by their relative working groups
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:07): (i.e. at both ends)
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:07): this is by design
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:07): I understand that.

14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:08): you're missing what I'm suggesting.. as a way to identify specifically the css version that you're coding for, if future changes come out, the site would still display properly with the css version it's specified for.
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:08): just a thought I was having
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:08): nothing more. notion just occurred to me. similar to how other software compatibilities work
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:09): not "support for at least this version", mind you
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:09): I'm not missing what you're suggesting.
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:09): ah I thought you were going someplace else with that
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:10): still, I dream of a day when all browsers are created equal in support for the bloody standards :|
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:10): we're working on that :)
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:10): and unfortunately it's us web designers who let them get away with it
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (19:10): fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98: : did todd farhner basically invent the idea of switching mdoes via doctype?
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:10): and why it's gone on this damn long :)
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (19:11): there was a old mailing list post that @html5 linked to the other day that indicated that
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:11): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: it was someone on the ie/mac team; i'll ask tantek who it was
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (19:12): 14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf: btw the @supports rule that moz proposed will help with "versioning"
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:12): assuming the ua doesn't lie to you about what it supports
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:12): ah so, that .. is new and news to me. is that googleable ?
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:12): e.g. hasFeature
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:13): google for 'css feature queries' or some such
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (19:13): fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98: yeah. the specificity of @support is nice tho
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:13): wait, that makes the css sound even more messy than designing sites for multiple mobile browsers and serving different styles/doctypes depending
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (19:13): and that you just say exactly the prop:value pair you wanna use
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (19:13): no it doesntttttttttt
14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf (19:14): maybe I better look at the spec before I open my mouth any more LOL
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (19:16): 14937780ed1da4f4e381c73a0e0c9dbf: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2011Apr/0428.html
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (19:16): thats the start of the thread
9cb4afde731e9eadcda4506ef7c65fa2 (19:37): how do i add rows to a table in html
9cb4afde731e9eadcda4506ef7c65fa2 (19:37): dpeending on the number of columns

d9d3cb22ec4f4fa022a95c197ca6871b (19:52): 9cb4afde731e9eadcda4506ef7c65fa2: it's been a while since I've needed that, but I always had an empty line, just with the table cells, and I cloned that via Javascript when I needed a new row.
6ab101787fafd9c7ae92ac33d17dfd2f (19:53): hi all

d9d3cb22ec4f4fa022a95c197ca6871b (19:53): 9cb4afde731e9eadcda4506ef7c65fa2: maybe someone has an updated better technic on that. I think it's better, performance-wise, to use some template language to generate the new html instead of cloning it.
49e2ba0575c840d273391f357c93c467 (19:54): the one which i pasted?
3e06fa3927cbdf4e9d93ba4541acce86 (19:58): You spell technic like a DJ
18d23e7e3397f5ffebebd0fd268b2446 (20:15): yay! yayquery :)
d9d3cb22ec4f4fa022a95c197ca6871b (20:22): yay! yaquery x2
3e06fa3927cbdf4e9d93ba4541acce86 (20:25): WHat does this effectively do?
3e06fa3927cbdf4e9d93ba4541acce86 (20:25): float: right;
3e06fa3927cbdf4e9d93ba4541acce86 (20:25): clear: right;
3e06fa3927cbdf4e9d93ba4541acce86 (20:25): Seems like the clear should be first
